metadata.description: The data set is mainly shown in the article https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pepi.2020.106617. The S-wave velocity structure under the station is obtained by using the joint inversion of the P-wave receiver function and the group velocity dispersion of 42 stations located near the Dahutang mining area in Jiangxi Province. The dataset contains 42 files in the format of DAT: for example, dahutang.jx46.velocity.dat. The data set represents the lithospheric velocity structure of the Dahutang mining area and understands the deep mechanism of Dahutang polymetallic mineralization.
metadata.instructions:
Data naming: the S-wave velocity structure is stored in text format, and the name of the file is "Dahutang.stnm.velocity.dat", where "stnm" represents the station name, such as Dahutang.JX01.velocity.dat Represents the S-wave velocity structure obtained by joint inversion of station JX01.
Data reading mode: all ASCII files in the data set can be directly opened using text editing software. 
The main contents: the first column station name, the second column station latitude (degree), the third column station longitude (degree), the fourth column depth (km), and the fifth column S-wave velocity (km/s).

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to determine the S-wave velocity structure beneath station sites in a mining area?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to determine the S-wave velocity structure beneath station sites in a mining area involves using P-wave receiver functions and group velocity dispersion. This approach utilizes data from 42 stations located near the Dahutang mining area to jointly invert and derive the S-wave velocity structure beneath each station.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features and methodologies involved in collecting and utilizing data to infer lithosphere velocity structures in mining areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: P-wave receiver functions, group velocity dispersion data, joint inversion, S-wave velocity structures

Quantification.Question: How many P wave receiving function and group velocity dispersion stations are used to obtain the S wave velocity structure in the lithosphere of the Dahutang mining area?

Definition.Question: What does 'P wave receiver function' mean in the context of lithospheric structure analysis?
Definition.Answer: P wave receiver function refers to a seismic data analysis technique used to infer the structure of the Earth's lithosphere by examining the conversions of P waves to S waves. This method utilizes seismic data collected from stations, in this case, 42 stations near the Dahutang mining area, to jointly invert P wave receiver functions and surface wave group velocity dispersion for determining the S wave velocity structure beneath the stations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the deployment strategy of seismic stations when collecting lithospheric structure data in mining areas like Dahutang?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The deployment strategy of seismic stations in mining areas like Dahutang is influenced by the need to adequately sample the subsurface S-wave velocity structure. Factors likely include the geological complexity of the area, the spatial distribution of mineral deposits, and the need for high-resolution data to understand the deep mechanisms of polymetallic mineralization.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of utilizing P wave receiver functions and group velocity dispersion in constructing a dataset for lithospheric structure analysis in mining areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to reveal the lithospheric velocity structure beneath mining areas like the Dahutang mineral district, which can provide insights into the deep mechanisms of polymetallic mineralization.
